metadata.subject: physics
metadata.dotPoint: describe gravitation, magnetism and electricity using a field model

field_definition.name: Field Definition
field_definition.formula: Field = region where non-contact force acts
field_definition.correct: A field is a region of space where each point is subject to a non-contact force. Objects do not need to touch to interact through fields.

a type of contact force.fix: Fields allow forces to act at a distance without physical contact between objects.
a type of contact force.action: List examples: gravity acts on a ball in mid-air (no contact), magnets attract through air (no contact).

an area with no forces.error: Opposite meaning. Fields are defined by the presence of forces.
an area with no forces.fix: A field exists precisely because forces act throughout that region of space.
an area with no forces.action: Think of Earth's gravitational field: forces act everywhere around Earth, not nowhere.

only exists between touching objects.error: That describes contact forces, not field forces.
only exists between touching objects.fix: The key feature of fields is action at a distance: no contact required.
only exists between touching objects.action: Consider how the Moon orbits Earth without touching it.

persistent.gap: You are confusing contact and non-contact forces.
persistent.action: Make a two-column table: contact forces (friction, normal force) vs non-contact forces (gravity, electric, magnetic).

field_lines_conventions.name: Field Line Conventions
field_lines_conventions.formula: Closer lines = stronger field; arrows show direction
field_lines_conventions.correct: Field lines show field direction (arrows) and strength (spacing). Closer lines indicate stronger fields. Lines never cross.

indicate the path objects follow.error: Field lines show force direction, not actual trajectories.
indicate the path objects follow.fix: Objects may curve through a field, but field lines show the force direction at each point.
indicate the path objects follow.action: A ball thrown horizontally curves downward, but gravitational field lines point straight down.

always form closed loops.error: Only magnetic field lines form closed loops. Electric and gravitational lines can begin and end on sources.
always form closed loops.fix: Magnetic lines loop from N to S. Electric lines start on + and end on −. Gravitational lines end at mass.
always form closed loops.action: Draw each field type and note which ones loop and which terminate.

show where the field is strongest at the.error: Line density (spacing) shows strength, not endpoints.
show where the field is strongest at the.fix: Where lines are closest together, the field is strongest. Where they spread apart, it is weaker.
show where the field is strongest at the.action: Look at field lines near Earth's surface vs far away: closer near surface = stronger field.

persistent.gap: You do not understand how field line diagrams convey information.
persistent.action: Draw field diagrams for a point mass, point charge, and bar magnet, annotating what spacing and direction indicate.

non_contact_force.name: Non-Contact Forces
non_contact_force.formula: Gravitational, electric, magnetic forces act at a distance
non_contact_force.correct: Non-contact forces act through empty space without objects touching. The three fundamental non-contact forces are gravitational, electric, and magnetic.

friction and tension.error: Friction and tension require physical contact between objects.
friction and tension.fix: Non-contact forces act at a distance: gravity, electricity, and magnetism work through empty space.
friction and tension.action: Test: does the force require surfaces to touch? If yes, it is a contact force.

normal force and gravity.error: Normal force requires contact; only gravity is a non-contact force.
normal force and gravity.fix: Normal force acts when surfaces press together. Gravity acts through empty space.
normal force and gravity.action: A book on a table: normal force requires contact, gravity acts even if the book floats in space.

all forces.error: Many forces require contact to act.
all forces.fix: Only gravitational, electric, and magnetic forces act without contact. Others like friction, tension, and normal force require touching.
all forces.action: Classify forces: push, pull, friction = contact; gravity, electric, magnetic = non-contact.

persistent.gap: You cannot distinguish contact from non-contact forces.
persistent.action: Create flashcards for 10 forces, sorting them into contact vs non-contact categories.

gravitational_field_direction.name: Gravitational Field Direction
gravitational_field_direction.correct: Gravitational field lines always point toward the mass creating the field. Gravity only attracts, never repels.

away from the mass.error: Reversed. Gravity pulls inward, not outward.
away from the mass.fix: Field lines show the direction a test mass would be pulled. All masses attract, so lines point toward the source.
away from the mass.action: Drop a ball: it falls toward Earth, not away. That is the field direction.

parallel to the surface.error: That describes uniform fields between plates, not point masses.
parallel to the surface.fix: Point masses create radial fields with lines pointing toward the centre.
parallel to the surface.action: Draw field around Earth: lines converge toward the centre, not sideways.

either toward or away from the mass.error: That describes electric fields, not gravitational.
either toward or away from the mass.fix: Electric fields can point either way (+ or − charges). Gravitational fields only point toward mass.
either toward or away from the mass.action: Key difference: mass only comes in one type (positive), so gravity only attracts.

persistent.gap: You are confusing gravitational and electric field directions.
persistent.action: Memorise: gravitational = always toward mass; electric = away from +, toward −.

gravitational_field_monopole.name: Gravitational Field as Monopole
gravitational_field_monopole.formula: Single type of mass → monopole field
gravitational_field_monopole.correct: Gravitational fields are monopoles because mass only comes in one type (no negative mass exists). All field lines point inward.

dipole.error: Dipoles require two opposite types. There is no negative mass.
dipole.fix: A dipole needs + and − ends, like a bar magnet. Since all mass is positive, gravity creates monopoles.
dipole.action: Compare: electric charge comes in +/−, but mass is always positive → monopole only.

quadrupole.error: Quadrupoles require four alternating poles. Mass cannot create this pattern.
quadrupole.fix: With only one type of mass, gravitational fields can only form monopoles.
quadrupole.action: Sketch a monopole (lines all inward) vs dipole (lines from N to S).

depends on the shape of the object.error: Shape affects field pattern but not the fundamental monopole nature.
depends on the shape of the object.fix: Whether spherical or irregular, gravitational fields are always monopoles because mass only attracts.
depends on the shape of the object.action: Consider: any mass configuration still has all field lines pointing inward.

persistent.gap: You do not understand why mass creates monopoles.
persistent.action: Write out: monopole = one type of source, dipole = two opposite types. Apply to mass vs charge vs magnetic poles.

electric_field_direction.name: Electric Field Direction
electric_field_direction.correct: Electric field lines point away from positive charges and toward negative charges. The direction shows how a positive test charge would move.

toward positive charges.fix: Field direction = direction a positive test charge would be pushed. Positive repels positive, so field points away.
toward positive charges.action: Place a + test charge near a + source: repulsion pushes it away = field away from +.

away from negative charges.fix: A positive test charge is attracted toward negative, so field points toward −.
away from negative charges.action: Place a + test charge near a − source: attraction pulls it toward = field toward −.

always toward the charge.error: That describes gravity, not electric fields.
always toward the charge.fix: Electric fields can point either way depending on charge sign. Gravity always attracts.
always toward the charge.action: Electric has both + and − charges; gravitational only has positive mass.

persistent.gap: You are confusing electric field direction with gravitational.
persistent.action: Draw both: gravitational field around mass (all inward) vs electric field around + and − charges (outward from +, inward to −).

electric_field_monopole_dipole.name: Electric Fields: Monopoles and Dipoles
electric_field_monopole_dipole.formula: Single charge = monopole; opposite charges = dipole
electric_field_monopole_dipole.correct: A single positive or negative charge creates a monopole field. Two opposite charges create a dipole field with lines from + to −.

always monopoles.error: Electric fields can be either monopoles or dipoles.
always monopoles.fix: One charge alone = monopole. Two opposite charges together = dipole.
always monopoles.action: Single + charge: lines radiate outward (monopole). + and − together: lines curve from + to − (dipole).

always dipoles.error: A single isolated charge creates a monopole.
always dipoles.fix: Dipoles require both + and − charges. A lone charge creates a monopole pattern.
always dipoles.action: Draw field around isolated electron: lines point inward toward it (monopole).

neither monopoles nor dipoles.error: Electric fields are definitely classified as monopoles or dipoles.
neither monopoles nor dipoles.fix: The classification depends on charge configuration: single charge = monopole, opposite pair = dipole.
neither monopoles nor dipoles.action: Practice drawing both configurations and labeling them correctly.

persistent.gap: You do not understand monopole vs dipole classification for electric fields.
persistent.action: Create a summary table: gravitational = always monopole; electric = monopole or dipole; magnetic = always dipole.

magnetic_field_direction.name: Magnetic Field Direction
magnetic_field_direction.formula: From north pole to south pole (external to magnet)
magnetic_field_direction.correct: Magnetic field lines point from the north pole to the south pole outside the magnet. Inside the magnet, they point from south to north, forming closed loops.

from south to north.fix: Outside the magnet: N → S. Inside the magnet: S → N. This creates closed loops.
from south to north.action: A compass needle aligns with field lines, with the north end pointing toward S pole.

toward the nearest pole.error: Direction depends on which pole (N or S), not just proximity.
toward the nearest pole.fix: Lines always exit north and enter south, regardless of distance.
toward the nearest pole.action: Trace a field line: starts at N pole, curves through space, enters S pole.

perpendicular to the poles.error: Lines emerge from and enter poles, not perpendicular to them.
perpendicular to the poles.fix: Field lines leave the N pole and curve around to enter the S pole.
perpendicular to the poles.action: Visualise iron filings around a bar magnet: they align tangent to field lines, not perpendicular.

persistent.gap: You cannot visualise magnetic field direction correctly.
persistent.action: Draw a bar magnet with field lines, tracing each line from N to S outside, S to N inside.

magnetic_field_dipole.name: Magnetic Fields as Dipoles
magnetic_field_dipole.formula: Always have N and S poles → always dipoles
magnetic_field_dipole.correct: Magnetic fields are always dipoles because magnetic poles always come in pairs. You cannot isolate a north or south pole.

monopoles.error: Magnetic monopoles have never been observed.
monopoles.fix: Cut a magnet in half and you get two smaller dipoles, each with N and S. No isolated pole exists.
monopoles.action: Consider: breaking a bar magnet creates two bar magnets, not separate N and S poles.

either monopoles or dipoles.error: Magnetic fields are only dipoles in nature.
either monopoles or dipoles.fix: Unlike electric charges (which can be isolated), magnetic poles always come in pairs.
either monopoles or dipoles.action: Compare: a single electron has charge (monopole possible), but no single N or S pole exists.

depends on the shape of the magnet.error: Shape does not change the dipole nature.
depends on the shape of the magnet.fix: Any magnet, regardless of shape, has both N and S poles. The field is always a dipole.
depends on the shape of the magnet.action: Even a spherical magnet has N and S regions; the field loops from one to the other.

persistent.gap: You do not understand why magnetic fields are always dipoles.
persistent.action: Research magnetic monopoles: why physicists have searched for them but never found them.

field_attraction_repulsion.name: Attraction and Repulsion in Fields
field_attraction_repulsion.formula: Gravity: attract only; Electric/Magnetic: attract AND repel
field_attraction_repulsion.correct: Gravity only attracts (mass only comes in one type). Electric charges and magnetic poles can attract or repel depending on whether they are like or opposite.

all fields only attract.fix: Electric: like charges repel, opposite attract. Magnetic: like poles repel, opposite attract. Gravity: always attract.
all fields only attract.action: Test with magnets: N-N repel, N-S attract. Test with charges: +/+ repel, +/− attract.

all fields can attract and repel.fix: There is no negative mass, so gravity cannot repel. Electric and magnetic fields can do both.
all fields can attract and repel.action: Think: what would repulsive gravity look like? Objects flying apart. This does not happen.

gravity can repel at large distances.error: Gravity always attracts regardless of distance.
gravity can repel at large distances.fix: The inverse square law reduces gravitational strength with distance, but it never reverses direction.
gravity can repel at large distances.action: Consider galaxies: even at vast distances, gravity pulls them together, never apart.

persistent.gap: You do not understand the fundamental difference between gravitational and electromagnetic interactions.
persistent.action: Create a comparison chart: force type, can attract?, can repel?, why?

uniform_vs_nonuniform.name: Uniform vs Non-Uniform Fields
uniform_vs_nonuniform.formula: Uniform: same magnitude and direction everywhere; Non-uniform: varies
uniform_vs_nonuniform.correct: A uniform field has constant magnitude and direction at all points (parallel, equally spaced lines). A non-uniform field varies in strength or direction across space.

uniform means the field exists everywher.error: Uniform refers to constancy of the field, not its extent.
uniform means the field exists everywher.fix: Uniform means same strength and direction at every point in the region, not that it covers all space.
uniform means the field exists everywher.action: Between parallel plates: field is uniform (same E everywhere). Around a point charge: non-uniform (E changes with r).

non-uniform means the field is weak.fix: A non-uniform field can be strong in some regions and weak in others. The key is that it changes.
non-uniform means the field is weak.action: Near Earth's surface: g ≈ 9.8 m/s² (approximately uniform). Far from Earth: g varies significantly (non-uniform).

all fields around point sources are unif.fix: Field strength decreases with distance from a point source (inverse square law), making it non-uniform.
all fields around point sources are unif.action: Calculate g at 1 Earth radius vs 2 Earth radii: different values = non-uniform.

persistent.gap: You confuse uniform fields with the existence of fields.
persistent.action: Draw parallel plate capacitor (uniform E) vs point charge (non-uniform E). Note line spacing in each.

static_vs_changing_fields.name: Static vs Changing Fields
static_vs_changing_fields.formula: Static: constant over time; Changing: varies with time
static_vs_changing_fields.correct: A static field does not change over time (stationary sources, constant currents). A changing field varies with time (moving sources, varying currents).

static means the field is not moving thr.error: Static refers to constancy in time, not spatial movement.
static means the field is not moving thr.fix: A static field has the same value at each point over time. It is not about the field moving.
static means the field is not moving thr.action: A stationary point charge: static electric field. The field itself does not move, but that is not why it is static.

changing means the field is getting stro.error: Changing could mean stronger, weaker, or different direction.
changing means the field is getting stro.fix: A changing field is one that varies over time in any way: magnitude, direction, or both.
changing means the field is getting stro.action: An AC current creates a changing magnetic field: it oscillates in direction, not just strength.

all magnetic fields are changing.error: Magnetic fields from permanent magnets at rest are static.
all magnetic fields are changing.fix: A stationary bar magnet creates a static magnetic field. A moving magnet creates a changing field.
all magnetic fields are changing.action: Test: place a magnet on a table. Is the field constant over time? Yes = static.

persistent.gap: You do not understand the time-dependence criterion for static vs changing fields.
persistent.action: List scenarios: stationary charge (static E), moving charge (changing E), steady current (static B), AC current (changing B).
